title: 114_s2526
content: The Act is titled the "Made in America Manufacturing Communities Act of 2016" and establishes a program to designate and support manufacturing communities. The Secretary will establish a program to improve US manufacturing competitiveness by designating consortiums as manufacturing communities and supporting them. The program aims to enhance US manufacturing competitiveness by designating consortiums as manufacturing communities and providing support to these designated communities. Members of these consortiums can receive preferential consideration for financial or technical assistance under participating programs. Members of consortiums designated as manufacturing communities may receive preferential consideration for financial or technical assistance from participating agencies if consistent with the economic development strategy of the consortium. Members of consortiums designated as manufacturing communities may receive preferential consideration for financial or technical assistance from participating agencies such as the Department of Agriculture and the Department of Commerce, as long as they meet all applicable requirements and align with the economic development strategy of the consortium. The participating agencies for the program include the Department of Agriculture, Commerce, Defense, Education, Energy, Housing and Urban Development, Labor, and Transportation. The participating agencies for the program include the Department of Agriculture, Commerce, Defense, Education, Energy, Housing and Urban Development, Labor, Transportation, Appalachian Regional Commission, Delta Regional Authority, Environmental Protection Agency, National Science Foundation, and Small Business Administration. The National Science Foundation and the Small Business Administration are participating agencies that will identify applicable programs for the established program under subsection (b). The participating agencies will identify programs for the established program under subsection (b), including those from manufacturing communities seeking financial or technical assistance. The participating agency may determine preference for financial or technical assistance among members of a manufacturing community consortium. Coordination is required in such cases. The agency may select members of a consortium for preference in financial or technical assistance. Coordination is required among selected members in developing their applications. The agency may require selected members of a consortium to coordinate in developing applications for financial or technical assistance. Participating agencies must submit a report to the Secretary on how they will give preferential consideration. The Secretary has the authority to provide technical assistance. The participating agency must report to the Secretary on how preferential consideration will be given. The Secretary can provide technical assistance to designated manufacturing communities. Financial and technical assistance is available under the program established by the head of the participating agency. Financial and technical assistance can be awarded to members of a consortium designated as a manufacturing community under a program established by the head of a participating agency. Financial and technical assistance can be used to support investments in ecosystems that enhance the competitiveness of U.S. manufacturing within designated manufacturing communities. Financial and technical assistance can be used to support investments in infrastructure, access to capital, and promotion of exports and foreign direct investment to improve the competitiveness of United States manufacturing. The following support areas for United States manufacturing competitiveness include infrastructure, access to capital, promotion of exports and foreign direct investment, equipment or facility upgrades, workforce training or retraining, energy or process efficiency, business incubators, site preparation, and advanced research. The Secretary of Commerce coordinates with participating agencies to identify programs for manufacturing competitiveness, including workforce training, energy efficiency, business incubators, site preparation, and advanced research. The Secretary coordinates with participating agencies to identify programs for manufacturing competitiveness and designates manufacturing communities to avoid duplication of efforts and leverage complementary activities. The Secretary designates eligible consortiums as manufacturing communities through a competitive process to promote manufacturing competitiveness and avoid duplication of efforts. Eligible consortiums represent defined regions. Eligible consortiums, defined by regions, must include an institution of higher education, a private sector entity, and a government entity. Private sector partners may also be included. The eligible consortiums must include an institution of higher education, a private sector entity, and a government entity. Private sector partners, institutions of higher education, government entities, economic development and community groups, financial institutions, and utilities may also be included. The eligible consortiums must include an institution of higher education, a private sector entity, and a government entity. The lead applicant can be a district organization, an Indian tribe, community and labor groups, financial institutions, or utilities. The eligible entities for the program include an Indian tribe, a State or political subdivision, and a consortium of Indian tribes or States engaged in economic or infrastructure development activities. The eligible entities for the program include a subdivision of a State, special purpose units of a State or local government, institutions of higher education, and public or private nonprofit organizations. The program is open to entities such as subdivisions of a State, special purpose units of a State or local government, institutions of higher education, and public or private nonprofit organizations. A consortium may define the region it represents with approval from the Secretary. A consortium can define its represented region with approval from the Secretary, ensuring it contains key technologies and allows for close collaboration. Each designation lasts for 2 years and can be renewed. Each consortium must be small enough for close collaboration and is designated for 2 years, with the possibility of renewal for another 2 years upon application. The Secretary may renew a consortium's designation for 2 years, with the option for another 2-year renewal upon application, allowing for modifications in composition. The Secretary may renew a consortium's designation for 2 years, with the option for another 2-year renewal upon application, allowing for modifications in composition such as adding or removing members. The Secretary evaluates eligible consortiums for renewal based on performance against previous designation terms and any post-designation awards received. The consortium's renewal evaluation includes assessing progress on project-specific metrics proposed in the application, especially those aimed at tracking community progress. The evaluation of the consortium's renewal focuses on assessing progress on project-specific metrics to track community progress and determine if any changes to the consortium or its strategy would enhance U.S. manufacturing competitiveness. The eligible consortium must submit an application for designation to the Secretary, including appropriate criteria and details as required. The eligible consortium must submit an application to the Secretary, including details like regional boundaries and manufacturing concentration assessment. The eligible consortium must submit an application to the Secretary, including details on manufacturing concentration assessment and competitive ranking nationally. An integrated assessment of the local industrial ecosystem of the region of the consortium, including workforce, training, supplier network, research, innovation, infrastructure, trade, international investment, operational improvements, and capital access components. The curr_chunk focuses on developing components of the industrial ecosystem selected by the consortium through specific investments and manufacturing. The consortium plans to make specific investments to address gaps in the industrial ecosystem and enhance the region's manufacturing competitiveness. They will also describe their proposed investments and implementation strategy to fill these gaps. The consortium will track outcome-based metrics, benchmarks, and milestones to evaluate their manufacturing community strategy and performance in improving manufacturing in the region. The consortium will evaluate the manufacturing community strategy by tracking outcome-based metrics and regional cooperation levels in the applications received. The consortium will evaluate applications based on regional cooperation and national manufacturing competitiveness. Previously recognized manufacturing communities will be considered. Each consortium previously designated as a manufacturing community by the Secretary under the Investing in Manufacturing Communities Partnership initiative will be recognized as a manufacturing community under this subsection. The Secretary may accept transferred funds from other participating entities. The Secretary may accept transferred funds from other participating agencies to carry out the manufacturing community initiative.
